properties.name: Missouri Headwaters State Park
properties.description: Where the Jefferson, Madison, and Gallatin rivers converge to form the mighty Missouri River. This is where Lewis and Clark first discovered the headwaters in 1805.
properties.story: On July 25, 1805, Captain William Clark became the first Euro-American to reach this sacred confluence. The expedition named the three rivers after President Thomas Jefferson, Secretary of State James Madison, and Secretary of the Treasury Albert Gallatin.

properties.name: Madison Buffalo Jump State Park
properties.description: For over 2,000 years, Native American tribes drove buffalo herds over these cliffs. One of the most significant archaeological sites in Montana.
properties.story: Imagine hundreds of bison thundering across the prairie, driven by skilled hunters toward the cliff edge. This site tells the story of ingenious hunting techniques that sustained tribes for millennia.

properties.name: Lewis and Clark Caverns State Park
properties.description: Montana's first and best-known state park. Guided tours take you through spectacular limestone caverns filled with stalactites, stalagmites, and other formations.
properties.story: Discovered in 1892, these caves are among the largest known limestone caverns in the Northwest. The 2-mile guided tour descends 600 feet through cathedral-like chambers adorned with nature's sculptures.

properties.name: Headwaters Trail System
properties.description: Award-winning paved trail along the historic Milwaukee Railroad bed. Named Montana Trail of the Year in 2007.
properties.story: Follow the path of the historic Milwaukee Railroad through cottonwood groves and past serene ponds. The trail ends at the Jefferson River with stunning views of the Tobacco Root Mountains.

properties.name: Sacajawea Hotel
properties.description: Built in 1910, this beautifully restored hotel is a Montana landmark. Home to Pompey's Grill and the Sac Bar.
properties.story: Named for the Lemhi Shoshone woman who guided Lewis and Clark, this elegant hotel has welcomed travelers for over a century. The restored Victorian charm makes every visit feel like stepping back in time.

properties.name: Headwaters Heritage Museum
properties.description: Discover the rich history of Three Forks and the surrounding area through exhibits on Lewis and Clark, Native American heritage, and pioneer life.
properties.story: From ancient Native American camps to the arrival of Lewis and Clark, from the railroad boom to modern ranching - this museum tells the complete story of life at the headwaters.

properties.name: Headwaters Golf Course
properties.description: Scenic 9-hole public course with stunning mountain views. Built in 1988, it offers a relaxed Montana golf experience.
properties.story: Play a round surrounded by deer, geese, and the majestic backdrop of the Tobacco Root and Bridger mountain ranges. A hidden gem for golfers seeking natural beauty.

properties.name: Three Forks Ponds
properties.description: Popular local swimming hole and recreation area. Perfect for summer days with swimming, fishing, and picnicking.
properties.story: Cool off in the crystal-clear waters fed by natural springs. Locals have been gathering here for generations - it's the perfect summer escape.

properties.name: Stevenson Park
properties.description: The heart of Three Forks recreation with covered pavilion, playground, tennis courts, sand volleyball, and seasonal kids pool.

properties.name: John Q. Adams Milwaukee Railroad Park
properties.description: Historic park honoring the railroad heritage that built Three Forks. Features original railroad artifacts and connects to the Headwaters Trail.
properties.story: The Milwaukee Railroad brought prosperity and growth to Three Forks. This park preserves that legacy and serves as the gateway to the beloved Headwaters Trail System.

properties.name: Three Forks Rodeo Arena
properties.description: Home of the Three Forks NRA Rodeo and various community events throughout the year.
properties.story: Experience authentic Montana cowboy culture at the annual NRA Rodeo. Bull riding, barrel racing, and bronc busting under the big sky - it doesn't get more Western than this.

properties.name: Veterans Memorial Park
properties.description: A peaceful park honoring those who served. Features memorials and quiet reflection spaces.

properties.name: Sacajawea Park
properties.description: Named for the famous Lemhi Shoshone guide, this park offers green space and connection to Three Forks' Lewis and Clark heritage.

properties.name: Three Forks KOA
properties.description: Full-service campground with RV sites, tent camping, and cabins. Great base for exploring the area.

properties.name: Jefferson River Access
properties.description: Popular fishing access point on the Jefferson River. Known for excellent trout fishing and scenic float trips.
properties.story: The Jefferson River offers some of Montana's finest blue-ribbon trout fishing. Named by Lewis and Clark for President Jefferson, it flows through pristine mountain valleys.

properties.name: Madison River Access
properties.description: World-renowned trout fishing on the Madison River. A bucket-list destination for fly fishers.
properties.story: The Madison is consistently rated one of the top 100 trout streams in America. Its riffles and runs hold wild rainbow and brown trout that challenge anglers from around the world.

properties.name: Gallatin River Access
properties.description: The third of the three forks, offering excellent fishing, kayaking, and scenic beauty.
properties.story: Flowing from Yellowstone National Park through the spectacular Gallatin Canyon, this river completes the trio that forms the Missouri. Its cold, clear waters are perfect for summer adventures.
